docs.lead_paragraph: A year ago, Sue Spiegel, 33, a television producer, didn't know a blitz from a blintz and assumed ''first and 10'' was a Manhattan street address. But on Sunday, after a year of weekly football workouts, she will be in front of the television, second-guessing Super Bowl strategy and empathizing with the players. Ms. Spiegel now has a good idea of how hard football players work, thanks to a football program run by Bob Shaw, a personal trainer and the owner of Physical Structure, a New York City health club. Last year, he added 40 minutes of offensive passing drills to his one-on-one training sessions to coax a dozen of his 90 female clients into running sprints.

headline.main: For Women, a Touchdown Pass to Fitness

docs.abstract: Bob Shaw, personal trainer in New York City and owner of Physical Structure, a health club, is offering 40-minute football-style offensive passing drills to coax his female clients into running sprints (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A practice that could pass as a Draconian punishment for perjury, tongue piercing, has pushed its way into youth culture -- and the trend is alarming many dentists. The American Dental Association passed a resolution at its 139th Annual Session, held recently in San Francisco, to oppose oral piercing, which it considers a public health hazard.

headline.main: Lurking Perils on the Tip of the Tongue

docs.abstract: American Dental Assn passes resolution at its 139th annual meeting in San Francisco opposing oral piercing, which it considers public health hazard; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Today's amusement park rides are faster, scarier and more elaborate than ever, and some theme park visitors are clutching their stomachs and opting for the sidelines. In an effort to help patrons who want to board roller coasters in spite of their fears, Universal Studios Islands of Adventure in Orlando, Fla., is offering the first stress-management program for apprehensive riders, led by two psychologists.

headline.main: Terrified, but Feeling Good About It

docs.lead_paragraph: Head throbbing, nose dripping, my friend Alison made the serious error of trying to apply deductive logic to the contents of the cold and cough aisle of her local supermarket a few months ago. If her usual brand of antihistamine worked for her usual runny nose, she reasoned, then surely the ''maximum strength sinus'' version of the same brand was what she needed for whatever evil combination of allergy, congestion and cold was causing her current misery.

headline.main: Amid the Antihistamines, a Quest for Logic

docs.abstract: Guidelines for finding most effective cold, cough and flu medications; list of active ingredients found in most cold and flu medications; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: What was I doing on this snow-covered hillside, trying to make artful turns on my cross-country skis? I gave up downhill skiing in the first place, nearly 20 years ago, because I was too nervous to ski with enough confident speed to carve classy turns and handle the big, steep, mogul-filled hills. But now I was deep into the ''telemark,'' a technique I had avoided for years. Developed about 100 years ago and named for a region in Norway, telemarking is something like a hybrid of cross-country and downhill skiing. Telemarkers use skis with a free heel and employ a series of turns to navigate a serious mountain and to ski through the magnificent vistas of untracked back country.

headline.main: Mastering the Practical Curtsy, on Skis

docs.abstract: The Novice column describes executing 'telemark' technique in cross-country skiing; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: So far the flu season has been as mild as the weather, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta -- although it may not seem that way for anyone who has wrestled with a bout. But that does not mean that the pattern will continue. In an update released last week, the agency warned that infections had been on the upswing since mid-December and that flu activity might increase through the winter.

headline.main: Rise in Infections Could Turn Mild Flu Season Nasty

docs.abstract: Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta warns that influenza infections have been on upswing since mid-December and that flu activity might increase through winter (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: This is the season to be miserable. Every other person seems to be down with something. But what? Is it ''just a cold'' or are you suffering from something more serious like the flu, bronchitis, sinusitis or perhaps pneumonia? Or could it be an allergy? Knowing what you have can make a big difference in how you feel, the treatment you require and your chances for relapse and lingering fatigue.

headline.main: A Defensive Strategy When Winter Ills Hit

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on sorting out the symptoms of various illnesses that beset people in winter; advice on distinguishing between colds and the flu; comments on bacterial invasions, and allergies; table of symptoms (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Eager to relieve the agonizing symptoms of winter viruses, sufferers are widening the search for remedies well beyond the conventional treatments. But even as Americans gobble $12 million worth of vitamins, herbs and supplements annually, scientists and others say there is not enough solid research to evaluate their effectiveness. That, however, is beginning to change.

headline.main: Remedy Research: Some Hints, Few Answers

docs.abstract: Review of recent findings about alternative medicine and therapies, vitamins, herbs and supplements for treating winter viruses; photo of garlic (M)
